Moulton and Milligan lay out the connections to court language moderately extensively. N. T. Wright in _Justification_ makes the claim that this root (at least as used by Paul) has to do with "having been found in favor of" in court--whether actually morally right or not.  But 1 Jn 3:7, for example, "ὁ ποιῶν τὴν δικαιοσύνην δίκαιός ἐστιν," cannot be "he who does find in favor is found in favor". Polybius *Histories* 9.10.5-6:

5 εἰ δ᾽ ἁπλουστάτοις χρώμενοι βίοις καὶ πορρωτάτω τῆς ἐν τούτοις περιττότητος καὶ πολυτελείας ἀφεστῶτες ὅμως ἐπεκράτουν τούτων αἰεὶ παρ᾽ οἷς ὑπῆρχε πλεῖστα καὶ κάλλιστα τὰ τοιαῦτα, πῶς οὐ νομιστέον εἶναι τὸ γινόμενον ὑπ᾽ αὐτῶν ἁμάρτημα; 6 τὸ γὰρ ἀπολιπόντας τὰ τῶν νικώντων ἔθη τὸν τῶν ἡττωμένων ζῆλον ἀναλαμβάνειν, προσεπιδραττομένους ἅμα καὶ τὸν ἐξακολουθοῦντα τοῖς τοιούτοις φθόνον, ὃ πάντων ἐστὶ φοβερώτατον ταῖς ὑπεροχαῖς, ὁμολογούμενον ἂν εἴποι τις εἶναι τῶν πραττόντων παράπτωμα.

5 But if, on the contrary, while leading the simplest of lives, very far removed from all such superfluous magnificence, they were constantly victorious over those who possessed the greatest number and finest examples of such works, must we not consider that they committed a mistake (ἁμάρτημα)? 6 To abandon the habits of the victors and to imitate those of the conquered, not only appropriating the objects, but at the same time attracting that envy which is inseparable from their possession, which is the one thing most to be dreaded by superiors in power, is surely an incontestable error (παράπτωμα).

James Whitley, _The Archaeology of Ancient Greece_: "Polis is usually translated as 'city-state' in English, as if at the centre of every Greek state was a city, every city having its own land or territory. Not all Greek states however were 'city-centred' states of this kind. In western Greece another kind of polity - the ethnos - prevailed. Ethne [plural of ethnos] were federal states, states made up of a number of large villages or small towns... Even 'city-centred' states like Argos, Corinth, and Athens were less urban than the term 'city-state' might imply."

\u03b1\u1f50\u03b8\u03b5\u03bd\u03c4\u03: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1_Timothy_2:12 is fascinating. Given that the applications are broad in their contexts, IMO the word must itself be abstract, and should not be reduced to a specific concrete meaning based on the local context. IMO, that abstract meaning comes, on the one hand, from its parts αὐτός="self-" and ἐντός="-within" (or more at ἔντοσθε "from within", although any derivation here is uncertain), and on the other, from a social perspective given a world of strict hierarchy, to mean "act from within oneself, as opposed to being directed by superiors". When one has no superiors, this is proper and can mean "authority"; when one has a superior, it is improper. Small wonder that most of the cases involve violence, then, since the pressure to be subordinate was so strong.

If προσκυνέω comes from κυνέω, then [Odysseus 21.224](http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:abo:tlg,0012,002:21:224&lang=original) says:

    τὼ δ᾽ ἐπεὶ εἰσιδέτην εὖ τ᾽ ἐφράσσαντο ἕκαστα,
    κλαῖον ἄρ᾽ ἀμφ᾽ Ὀδυσῆϊ δαΐφρονι χεῖρε βαλόντε,
    καὶ κύνεον ἀγαπαζόμενοι κεφαλήν τε καὶ ὤμους
    ὣς δ᾽ αὔτως Ὀδυσεὺς κεφαλὰς καὶ χεῖρας ἔκυσσε.
    .
    but when they who had been showed looked in well,
    they were crying then on both sides to wise Odysseus who threw hands
    and κύνεον who love head and shoulders as well
    but similarly Odysseus ἔκυσσε head and hands

"and loving, they were kissing head and shoulders as well" is the popular translation, assuming κύνεον to be a form of the verb "to kiss" as "ἔκυσσε" is in the next line. I'm not convinced it's not "bowing head and shoulders".

But [Herodotus 1.134](http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:abo:tlg,0016,001:1:134&lang=original) says:

    ἐντυγχάνοντες δ᾽ ἀλλήλοισι ἐν τῇσι ὁδοῖσι,
    τῷδε ἄν τις διαγνοίη εἰ ὅμοιοί εἰσὶ οἱ συντυγχάνοντες:
    ἀντὶ γὰρ τοῦ προσαγορεύειν ἀλλήλους φιλέουσι τοῖσι στόμασι:
    ἢν δὲ ᾖ οὕτερος ὑποδεέστερος ὀλίγῳ, τὰς παρειὰς φιλέονται:
    ἢν δὲ πολλῷ ᾖ οὕτερος ἀγεννέστερος, προσπίπτων προσκυνέει τὸν ἕτερον.

    but meeting one another in the streets,
    anyone might ever distinguish if those who meet are equals
    for instead of addressing they kiss (φιλέουσι, "show affection") on the lips;
    but were one or the other being a little inferior, kissing (φιλέονται, "showing affection") the cheeks;
    but were one or the other extremely low-born, falling toward προσκυνέει the other.

προσκυνέω should probably be read as "bowing to". As BDAG puts it, "freq used to designate the custom of prostrating oneself before persons and kissing their feet or the hem of their garment, the ground, etc."

\u03bd\u03cc\u03bc\u03bf\u03c2:
LSJ: "custom, usage, law" but distinct from θεσμός "that which is laid down and established"

"…Cleisthenes [b 580 BC] has been credited with a significant change in Greek political vocabulary, the application of the word nomos, instead of the traditional thesmos, to designate statutory law. What is significant about this change is that, while thesmos implies the imposition of law from above and has a distinctly religious flavour, nomos — a word that suggests something held in common, whether a pasture or a custom — implies a law to which there is common agreement, something that people who are subject to it themselves regard as a binding norm. The application of nomos to a statue became common usage in Athens, which had thereby adopted ‘the most democratic word for “law” in any language’." — Ellen Meiksins Wood, Citizens to Lords, p. 36 (from http://fragments.awedge.net/?p=1210)

...but neither is it ψήφισμα: "In the fourth century...Nomos meant a general norm without limit of duration, whereas psephisma meant an individual norm which, once carried out, was emptied of its content" The Athenian Democracy in the Age of Demosthenes: Structure, Principles, and ...
 By Mogens Herman Hansen p162

"Nomos is primarily, though not exclusively, written law or custom. Thesmos is unwritten law, divine (in the Greek sense) or natural...This particular thesmos [of P-Dio] does not appear in Scripture, of course. It refers to the Neoplatonist universal substrate of hierarchic order, the basis of the transmission of good from higher to lower levels. Thesmos is universal cosmic order" Hierarchy and the Definition of Order in the Letters of Pseudo-Dionysius By Ronald F. Hathaway

commonly glossed as "think" or "seem", M&M, LSJ, etc. make the case that it has more to do with what one expects to do. In modern parlance, this is what it means to "believe" something; not the ecstatic "I believe!" but the reasoned "I *believe* it to be true, but I don't *know*".

The entire δοκ- group appears to hinge on the concept of watching to see how something will turn out, with greater and greater degrees of certainty:
 * δοκάω: watch closely
 * δοκεύω: keep an eye on
 * δοκέω: seem, believe
 * δοκιμάζω: assay

\u03bd\u03bf\u03bc\u03af\u03b6\u03c9:
"deem" is certainly archaic in 21st c English. Webster's 1828 defines it as "1. To think; to judge; to be of opinion; to conclude on consideration 2. To estimate." Given the passages we have in the NT, they all involve some measure of contradiction: whatever the actor deemed to be true wasn't. That is captured today by the word "assume".

The more difficult question is whether and how to tie this to νόμος.

LSJ: πειραστικός = "tentative" is perhaps the best approach to the semantics of this word. Any sense of "tempt" appears to be a theological over-systematization: πειρασμόν = "put to the test" but we're reading the Bible and that occasionally means "put to the test regarding one's resolve to resist temptation", therefore it always means "tempt". But the canonical basis for "tempt" is somehow LXX Deut 6:16 "Do not tempt God" as if he could be tempted--but he can be put to the test.

\u1f10\u03c1\u03c9\u03c4\u03ac\u03c9: Trench: "The distinction between aiteo and erotao is as follows. Aiteo is the more submissive and suppliant term. It is consistently used to refer to an inferior's seeking something from a superior (Acts 12:20), of a beggar's seeking alms from a potential donor (Acts 3:2), of a child's seeking something from a parent (Lam. 4:4; Matt. 7:9; Luke 6:11), of a subject's seeking something from a ruler (Ezra 8:22), and of a man's seeking something from God. In classical Greek, erotao never means "to ask" but only "to interrogate," or "to inquire." Like rogare (inquire), erotao implies an equality between the one who asks and the one who is asked as a king with another king (Luke 14:32)or if not equality, then a familiarity that lends authority to the request."

\u1f00\u03b3\u03b1\u03b8\u03cc\u03c2:
[Trench says](http://studybible.info/trench/Goodness), quoting Jerome: "chrestotes is a virtue willingly ready to do good. Agathosyne is not much different, for it also seems ready to do good. But it differs in that it can be more harsh and with a countenance wrinkled by strict standards for one to do well and to excel in what is demanded, without being pleasant to associates and attracting crowds by its sweetness. Also the followers of Zeno define it as follows: agathosyne is a virtue which is beneficial, or a virtue which promotes usefulness, or a virtue for its own sake, or a disposition which is the source of all benefits."

Throughout the NT, the word is often contrasted with πονηρός, but also κακός and φαῦλος.

\u03b4\u03b9\u03b1\u03c3\u03c0\u03ac\u03: Since σπάω means "to draw one's sword" I have a hard time believing δια+σπάω means "torn asunder" as Thayer would have it. Doesn't it rather mean "to draw through"? So In Mk 5:4, we get "the restraints were drawn through under him" meaning not just on his wrists but between his legs too. This also resolves the problem of the passive voice; if Thayer is right then it would be that the man *was torn* asunder by the restraints.

\u1f00\u03c0\u03cc\u03c3\u03c4\u03bf\u03: Moulton and Milligan note that "apostolos" in a nautical context is actually used for the "ship" itself. Indeed, if English had a better noun, I would render "apostello" as "ship" and "apostolos" as "shipper". But "envoy" will have to do instead. It has come to mean "diplomat" unfortunately, but its original was much broader.
\u1f10\u03ba\u03c0\u03b5\u03b9\u03c1\u03: LSJ: πειραστικός = "tentative" is perhaps the best approach to the semantics of this word. Any sense of "tempt" appears to be a theological over-systematization: πειρασμόν = "put to the test" but we're reading the Bible and that occasionally means "put to the test regarding one's resolve to resist temptation", therefore it always means "tempt". But the canonical basis for "tempt" is somehow LXX Deut 6:16 "Do not tempt God" as if he could be tempted--but he can be put to the test.
\u03b6\u1ff7\u03bf\u03bd: Why "animal" and not "living creature"? Because the latter is awkward in English, and I believe only preferred by some translations because it doesn't carry the connotation that these beings might be lesser beings. But LSJ notes that this word did carry that when used "contemptuously". We can pick and choose the connotations inherent in the translation but not those in the original.
\u03b6\u03b7\u03bc\u03b9\u03cc\u03c9: "lose" is typical but 1) the form is passive, and 2) we shouldn't conflict with ἀπόλλυμι ("let go", "lose") as in Lk 9:25 "δὲ ἀπολέσας ἢ ζημιωθείς". Therefore, "penalize" as M&M mention.
\u03b8\u03b5\u03c1\u03b1\u03c0\u03b5\u03: TDNT: "serve, treat, care for, heal". Although Jesus in particular performs complete healings, the norm (and therefore the common meaning of the word) was to "tend", not "heal" (which is more properly ἰάομαι, cf Lk 6:18). The passive aorist is a little tricky, cf Mt 17:18 "καὶ ἐθεραπεύθη ὁ παῖς ἀπὸ τῆς ὥρας ἐκείνης" ~= "and the child was tended from that hour" because it's too easy to read as a perfective in English ("was healed" would fare no better, being read as if "healed" were an adjective). The sense is more "the child was done being tended", just like one would say "the ball was kicked".
\u03b4\u03b1\u03b9\u03bc\u03cc\u03bd\u03: TDNT: Ancient Greek "daimon" used more for beings and "daimonion" (neuter) for "divinity" or "fate". Not necessarily evil in Gk thought, but mostly ignored in the OT.
\u1f00\u03c1\u03c7\u03ae: "beginning" is often used, but strays too far in my opinion from the sense of primacy in modern English, especially in that there is no form of the word which fits when "rulers" are denoted. For now, I'm compromising on "founders" and "founding" as needed to at least retain some phonetic linkage. I only wish I could do the same for ἀρχαῖος.

\u1f14\u03bb\u03b5\u03bf\u03c2:
Pity and Power in Ancient Athens (Rachel Hall Sternberg, ed): "Kleon urges the Athenians not to be led astray by oiktos. The reason that he offers is that eleos is right only in a context of reciprocal relations (Thuc. 3.40.2-3)...Could one of the two words imply that the pitier has the power to help the pitied and is inclined to do so? But the eighteen cases of pity where the pitier intervenes are almost evenly divided between oiktos and eleos." I'm not sure the latter bears on the former...the existence of a peer or patron relationship is not the same as the motivation to intervene. So Kleon may be right, and oiktos is for relationships where the pitier has so much more power that no reciprocity is expected.

But also (p 68) "In Homer's poetry, eleos appears more active, the giving of pity, as opposed to oiktos, the more passive feeling of pity, a restraint from inflicting further shame." That drives me to choose "compassion" for eleos and "pity" for oiktos.

    dialuo: dissolve

\u1f00\u03b3\u03b1\u03b8\u03c9\u03c3\u03:
[Trench says](http://studybible.info/trench/Goodness): "chrestotes is a virtue willingly ready to do good. Agathosyne is not much different, for it also seems ready to do good. But it differs in that it can be more harsh and with a countenance wrinkled by strict standards for one to do well and to excel in what is demanded, without being pleasant to associates and attracting crowds by its sweetness. Also the followers of Zeno define it as follows: agathosyne is a virtue which is beneficial, or a virtue which promotes usefulness, or a virtue for its own sake, or a disposition which is the source of all benefits."

> Rather than being a virtue that refers only to a person's words and countenance, chrestotes refers to a virtue that pervades and penetrates the whole nature, that mellows anything harsh and austere. Thus wine that has been mellowed with age (Luke 5:39) is chrestos, and Christ's yoke is chrestos, because it has nothing harsh or galling about it (Matt. 11:30). Cocceius distinguished chrestos and agathosyne this way: 

> From this example it is dear that this word [chrestotes] indicates a certain generosity and eagerness to do good. The other word [agathosyne] implies kindness, agreeableness of manners, eloquence, earnestness of character, and every amiability joined with propriety and dignity.

> Even that statement, however, is not exactly correct. If the words are contrasted, kindness belongs more to the chrestotes than to the agathosyne. Jerome's excellent statement is more germain to the matter:

> Benignitas [friendliness! or suavitas [kindness]since among the Greeks chrestotes signifies each, is a gentle, charming, and calm virtue, suited to the company of all good people, attracting their friendship, delightful in encouragement and moderate in manners. Also the Stoics define it thus: chrestotes is a virtue willingly ready to do good. Agathosyne is not much different, for it also seems ready to do good. But it differs in that it can be more harsh and with a countenance wrinkled by strict standards for one to do well and to excel in what is demanded, without being pleasant to associates and attracting crowds by its sweetness. Also the followers of Zeno define it as follows: agathosyne is a virtue which is beneficial, or a virtue which promotes usefulness, or a virtue for its own sake, or a disposition which is the source of all benefits.

> Jerome's statement essentially agrees with the distinction drawn by Basil: "I think chrestotes is more extensive in doing good to those who in any way at any time have need of it; agathosyne is more narrow and uses words of justice in its well-doing." Lightfoot found more activity in the agathosyne than in the chrestotes:"They are distinguished from one another as character from activity; chrestotes is potential agathosyne, while agathosyne is energizing chrestotes" 
A man may display his agathosyne, his zeal for goodness and truth, in rebuking, correcting, and chastising. Although Christ was still in the spirit of this virtue when he drove the buyers and sellers out of the temple (Matt. 21:13) and when he uttered all those terrible words against the scribes and the Pharisees (Matt. 23), we could not say that his chrestotes was shown in these acts of righteous indignation. Rather, his chrestotes was displayed in his reception of the penitent woman (Luke 7:37-50; cf. Ps. 25:6-7) and in all his other gracious dealings with the children of men. Thus we might speak of the chrestotes tes agathosynes of God, but scarcely of the converse. This chrestotes was so predominantly a part of the character of Christ's ministry that it is not surprising to learn from Tertullian how "Christus" became "Chrestus" and "Christiani" became "Chrestiani" on the lips of the heathen, though with an undertone of contempt. The world expresses contempt for goodness that seems to have only the harmlessness of the dove and not the wisdom of the serpent. Such a contempt would be justified for a goodness that has no edge, no sharpness, no righteous indignation against sin or willingness to punish it. Sometimes chrestotes degenerated into this and ended up being not goodness at all, as evidenced in this striking fragment of Menander: "What now by some is called kindness [chrestotes] has set loose entire lives to vice, for no one is punished for his wrongs."
\u1f10\u03be\u03ad\u03c1\u03c7\u03bf\u03:
"go/come out" is a trade-off:
    1. The decision to use "go" or "come" depends on the point of view of the narrator in English, which isn't always clear in Greek (unless it's a quotation).
    2. "come out" is often followed by "out of", and one of the "outs" has to go. It's no good replacing "come out" with "depart" or "exit", which typically sound archaic to the postmodern ear.

\u03ba\u03c1\u03b9\u03c4\u03ae\u03c2:
Often glossed as "judge", this should be distinguished from a "dikastes", a member of the (several hundred member) juries which decided cases in Greek courts. Paul Bullen makes the case [1] that krites was the more generic term, "both dikasts and ekklesiasts, who listen to judicial and deliberative speeches respectively, are kritai...It is only when Aristotle uses dikastês, dikazein, and dikê that we can be fairly sure than he means judge, judging, and judgment (or trial) in the specifically judicial sense." Since the other forms of this root are so easily rendered "decide" etc. I'm going with "decider" for now.


[1] http://paul.bullen.com/BullenLawmakers.html
Lawmakers and Ordinary People in Aristotle*
Paul Bullen (1996)
[Pages 229-42 (ch. 12) of Justice v. Law in Greek Political Thought, ed. Leslie G. Rubin (Lanham, Maryland: Rowman & Littlefield, 1997)]

\u1f51\u03c0\u03ac\u03c1\u03c7\u03c9:
A difficult word that has no single cognate in English. The primary meaning is "to (already) exist", in the sense of "an existing owner" or "existing as a ruler"--"existence" as "current", not "existence" as opposed to "nonexistence".

However, the most common use "τὰ ὑπάρχοντα" is more properly rendered in English as "belongings"; that is, "things which belong (to me)". In Koine, the phrase would have carried the sense of "things which exist (to me)", or "existings", which is awkward English. Compare Acts 3:2 with 3:6.

\u1f10\u03bd\u03c4\u03ad\u03bb\u03bb\u03: τέλος = "finish", τελέω = "to finish" and τέλλω = "to cause to finish". ἐντέλεια = "completeness". So no, ἐντέλλω does not mean "enjoin, command". What it means is to cause to finish in another, which can be accomplished via a command.

\u03b4\u03af\u03ba\u03b1\u03b9\u03bf\u03:
Moulton and Milligan lay out the connections to court language moderately extensively. N. T. Wright in _Justification_ makes the claim that this root (at least as used by Paul) has to do with "having been found in favor of" in court--whether actually morally right or not.  But 1 Jn 3:7, for example, "ὁ ποιῶν τὴν δικαιοσύνην δίκαιός ἐστιν," cannot be "he who does find in favor is found in favor". I tend more toward "the right" in the sense of "social expectations" a la Malina, therefore: "he who does what is proper is proper".

Being frequently contrasted with "ἁμαρτωλός", we might choose "successful" vs "failures". But that still doesn't fit 1 Jn 3:7. Perhaps "right" is as close as we can come in English, but I'm going to go with "proper" for now since "right" has come to suppose no judgment.

\u1f51\u03c0\u03c9\u03c0\u03b9\u03ac\u03:
LSJ: Not "ὑποπιάζω" (omicron), to "press slightly", but "ὑπωπιάζω" (omega), "to give a black eye". I'm not sure this is right. The translation appears to hinge on Aristotle's Rhetoric 3.11.15 (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0059%3Abook%3D3%3Achapter%3D11%3Asection%3D15):

"..., οἷον εἰς ὑπωπιασμένον “ᾠήθητε δ᾽ ἂν αὐτὸν εἶναι συκαμίνων κάλαθον”: ἐρυθρὸν γάρ τι τὸ ὑπώπιον, ἀλλὰ τοῦτο πολὺ σφόδρα."
"For instance, one may say of a man whose eye is all black and blue, “you would have thought he was a basket of mulberries,” because the black eye is something purple, but the great quantity constitutes the hyperbole."

But if we remove some of our translation assumptions in a more word-for-word style, we get:

"such as, into he who is under-eyed, “you would have thought he was a basket of mulberries,” for the under-eyes [are] somewhat red, but the many [are the] excess."

LSJ says ὑπώπιον is "under the eyes", but it is akin to ἐξώπιος "out of sight", ἐνώπιος "face to face", or πρόσωπον "facing", all from ὤψ "face, countenance". I have a hard time believing ὑπωπιάζω means "give a black eye"; that implies ἐνωπιάζω (if it existed) would mean "hit in the eye" and ἐξωπιάζω...what, "pluck out the eye"? I rather believe ὑπωπιάζω means "to lower in countenance", or "to lose face". Even though ὤψ ("eye") is the root, I believe it is consistently used to symbol the entire face and thereby one's social position. Under that concept, we obtain:

"such as, into he who is embarrassed, “you would have thought he was a basket of mulberries,” for the cheeks [are] somewhat red, but the many [are the] excess."

Therefore I've rendered 1 Cor 9:27 as "I make my body lose face and I lead it to slavery", and Lk 18:5 becomes "I will exact justice for her in order that not coming into the finish she might make me lose face."

\u03c3\u03c4\u03ad\u03bb\u03bb\u03bf\u03:
LSJ: "make ready, fit out" but also "summon", "furl", "restrict (one's diet)", presumably in combination with various prepositions. The cognitive model appears to be pulling/gathering a thing or set of things into its proper place (but not τάσσω = "arrange" more than one thing).

* ἀποστέλλω: organize away = commission
* διαστέλλω: organize between = dilate, disperse, define precisely
* συστέλλω: organize together = gather in, furl
* ὑποστέλλω: organize under = tuck under
* ἐπιστέλλω: organize upon = send a letter
* καταστέλλω: organize against = restrain

στέλλω and πέμπω (send) are not synonyms. Cf Herodotus, The Histories 5.64.1:
    μετὰ δὲ Λακεδαιμόνιοι μέζω στόλον στείλαντες ἀπέπεμψαν ἐπὶ τὰς Ἀθήνας
    After this the Lacedaemonians a greater expedition ______ (στέλλω) sent out (πέμπω) upon Athens
or, for a more contemporary example, Acts 11:13:
    Ἀπόστειλον εἰς Ἰόππην καὶ μετάπεμψαι Σίμωνα
    _____ away into Joppe and send after Simon

even though Matthew and Mark interchange them in the same story:
    Mk 5:12 Πέμψον ἡμᾶς εἰς τοὺς χοίρους (send us into the pigs)
    Mt 8:31 ἀπόστειλον ἡμᾶς εἰς τὴν ἀγέλην τῶν χοίρων (order us away into the herd of the pigs)
...Luke shows there's more than one way to tell a story without forcing all words to be synonyms of each other:
    Lk 8:32 ἵνα ἐπιτρέψῃ αὐτοῖς εἰς ἐκείνους εἰσελθεῖν (in order that he would turn over to them to enter into those)

στέλλω also needs to be distinguished from ἑτοιμάζω (make ready) and παρασκευάζω (prepare), and also from ἄρτιος (fit).

\u03c6\u03c5\u03c3\u03b9\u03cc\u03c9:
φυσάω is "to inflate", from φῦσα "bellows".

I'm explicitly avoiding here the common translation "puff up" because bellows (φῦσα) would have been primarily used to heat smith's fires rather than to inflate anything. Even with "όω" suffix, which usually indicates "to cause or to make", it doesn't seem likely that the verb means "to make a bellows" but rather "to use a bellows to push air". In Col 2:18 it may mean "puff up" because of the context (passive toward a person), but that's hardly a reason to skip the metaphor and replace the passive with an active; rather, it's more likely there to mean "being blown into" as if he were a furnace, being heated quickly and then cooling again.

But I might be leaning toward the JMNT which reads "being made natural and instinctual" for Colossians 2:18, considering the word to be a form of φύσις (nature, character) rather than φῦσα (bellows).

[Trench says](http://studybible.info/trench/Fair), "Initially, kalos referred to beauty, especially from the Greek viewpoint of that which is harmonious and complete, of something in which all the parts are balanced and proportionate. \u03c3\u03ba\u03ac\u03bd\u03b4\u03b1\u03: Rom 9:33 "πέτραν σκανδάλου" implies a deadfall trap (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapping#Deadfall_traps), so some of the uses which mention food could imply bait, and some which mention body parts could imply them being crushed, not snared. See also LSJ σκανδαλάριος, "shingler" (assuming rock or clay shingles), but also σκανδαλιστής "prob. acrobat who performed on a trapeze (σκάνδαλον)".
\u03b4\u03bf\u03be\u03ac\u03b6\u03c9:
TDNT: "This means 'opinion' as a. what I think, and b. what others think of me." Malina makes the compelling case that this is "honor" in agonistic societies. But "τιμή" also has this translation. TDNT says "τιμή as honor increasingly becomes inner worth as distinct from outward esteem." Could it be that δόξα retains the sense of "outward esteem", which is why it worked so well for "kabod" = "glory"? So let's try "revere" etc. for now.

Jn 7:39 is an interesting case "οὔπω γὰρ ἦν πνεῦμα, ὅτι Ἰησοῦς οὐδέπω ἐδοξάσθη" where "glorify" might be better.

\u03c7\u03c1\u03b7\u03bc\u03b1\u03c4\u03:
In many cases, this seems to be a distorted form of χράω (χρησμὸς) which means "to oracle": Mt 2:12, Mt 2:22, Lk 2:26, and Ac 10:22 all involve messages from God.

But not in Rom 7:3, where the meaning is more like the primary meanings in LSJ, "to negotiate, traffic, deal" (see also χρῆμα = "goods, property, money").
Heb 8:5 and 11:7 could go either way. Heb 12:25 is just weird. Ac 11:26 is unclear, too...seems many have glossed it as "first called Christians", but I have my doubts.
\u03b4\u03c9\u03c1\u03b5\u03ac: Something given out of largesse, a "gift". Given from patron to client. For the opposite, see δῶρον.
\u03c6\u03b9\u03bb\u03ad\u03c9: [Trench](http://studybible.info/trench/Love) makes the case that ἀγαπάω is closer to "esteem" and φιλέω more affectionate.
\u03c0\u03bb\u03b1\u03c4\u03b5\u1fd6\u03: From πλατύς "wide, broad" (but "flat", not εὐρύς "spacious"). The English word "plaza" is from the Latin "platea", the same PIE root "to spread".
\u03c0\u03b5\u03b9\u03c1\u03b1\u03c3\u03:
M&M: "try", "attempt". Need to keep this distinct from δοκίμιον = "test".

LSJ: πειραστικός = "tentative" is perhaps the best approach to the semantics of this word. Any sense of "tempt" appears to be a theological over-systematization: πειρασμόν = "put to the test" but we're reading the Bible and that occasionally means "put to the test regarding one's resolve to resist temptation", therefore it always means "tempt". But the canonical basis for "tempt" is somehow LXX Deut 6:16 "Do not tempt God" as if he could be tempted--but he can be put to the test.
\u1f51\u03c0\u03bf\u03b4\u03b5\u03af\u03: M&M: "example", "specimen" but neither of those has a simple verb form. So "illustrate".
\u03b5\u1f50\u03c6\u03c1\u03b1\u03af\u03: There isn't a word in English that can carry e.g. "be made to have good thoughts" very well. Slater uses "delighted" which I'll go with for now, even though it doesn't retain much connection with φρήν.
\u1f00\u03bd\u03b1\u03af\u03b4\u03b5\u03: Luke 11:8: that is, through the shamelessness of the one asking.
\u03c3\u03c7\u03af\u03b6\u03c9: This could be rendered "divide" or "separate" but all uses in the NT with respect to objects (rocks, curtains, wineskins) carry the connotation of destructive activity. With respect to groups of people, this is often rendered "dissension" or such; in these cases, too, "tearing" seems more violent but more in line with the original.
\u03c0\u03b5\u03c1\u03b9\u03c0\u03b1\u03: TDNT: peri = "around" + pateo = "walk" (intrans) and "tread" (trans). But the intrans of peripateo is not in the NT. So "walk around".
\u03c7\u03ac\u03c1\u03b9\u03bd: "for the favor of" which might be better glossed in English as "for the sake of", but in this version I want to keep the same root as χάρις = "favor".
\u03ba\u03cc\u03c0\u03c4\u03c9: LSJ: "cut, strike, smite". At first, I went with "cut" because it seemed to best fit the NT references to cutting branches etc. But "pounding in a mortar" etc make it clear that if this is ever "cut", it's not very sharp (perhaps κωφός is related in this way). Going with "chop" for now since that connotes duller instruments (or at least bigger tasks) and also works for e.g. "_____ him on the cheek". The senses of "hammer, forge, stamp" are served less well. "Hack" might be better?
\u03ba\u03b1\u03c4\u03b7\u03b3\u03bf\u03: TDNT says "accuse", but I prefer to use "challenge" because of the inclusion of the "agora" root, which implies a public forum. Malina would certainly consider this an agonistic battle for honor.
\u03c6\u03b1\u1fe6\u03bb\u03bf\u03c2: LSJ: easy, simple, common, mean (in both senses).
\u1f10\u03c0\u03b9\u03c4\u03b9\u03bc\u03: "epi" = "on top of" + "timao" = "honor". To exercise one's honor upon, which has been translated "rebuke" and so on, but I really want to expose the honor/shame dynamics throughout, so "subject"/"bring under one's control", whether disciples or demons, seems best.
\u1f04\u03b3\u03c9: LSJ: "lead, carry, fetch, bring, of living creatures, φέρω being used of things..."

ἱλήκω is closer to "grace".
\u03a3\u03cd\u03c1\u03c4\u03b9\u03c2: LSJ: "the Syrtis , name of two large shallow gulfs on the coast of Libya"
\u03c0\u03ad\u03bb\u03b1\u03b3\u03bf\u03: LSJ: "sea", but I'd like to find a distinction with θάλασσα = "sea". The Argonautica has "πέλαγός τε θαλάσσης" (see http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollon.%202.608&lang=original) which has been translated "expanse of sea" which isn't very satisfactory either. Using "flood" for now based on πελαγόω = "to flood" whereas θαλασσόω = "to change into sea" or "purify with sea-water", "of wine, to be mixed with sea-water".
\u1fe5\u03b9\u03c0\u03ae: LSJ: swing or force with which anything is thrown...flap, buzz, blink.
\u03ba\u03c1\u03b1\u03c4\u03ad\u03c9: M&M: "conquer", "rule", "master". Note that we must distinguish this from δύναμις. Apparently the opposite of ἀφίημι "leave alone"/"release" (John 20:23), the LSJ examples and NT cases all have to do with holding something still, whether a person or a teaching. But the other forms are so focused on strength/power that it must be more than "hold". Odd to be used also for supplicants seizing Jesus' feet.
\u1f10\u03ba\u03c7\u03ad\u03c9: "pour" or (M&M) "drain"? When it comes to blood, the most common object, "pour" is probably better, but if we're going to pick a different word there, we might as well go for "bleed".
\u03b4\u03b9\u03ac: genitive: by means of; accusative: because of
\u1f35\u03bb\u03b5\u03c9\u03c2: In Hebrews, "merciful" or "gracious" is fine (see ἐλεέω). In Matthew 16:22, however, both SBLGNT and NA have Ἵλεώς but both א (Codex Sinaiticus) and B (Codex Vaticanus) have ειλεωϲ (see http://codexsinaiticus.org/en/manuscript.aspx?book=33&chapter=16&verse=22). This may be an itacism but may instead be a form of εἴλω ("prevent") which would be an older word but not such an "elliptical expression" as https://net.bible.org/#!bible/Matthew+16:22 describes it. See also http://hermeneutics.stackexchange.com/questions/19570/what-is-the-correct-text-of-matthew-1622-in-the-codex-vaticanus

I choose "pass" because it's the closest English I can find that 1) comes close 2) is clearly passive when intransitive and 3) has lots of prepositional combinations like the Greek. Not "pass" as when ships pass in the night, but "passage".
\u03c8\u03c5\u03c7\u03ae: LSJ: Not ζωή: "living, property" or the opposite of death, but one's "conscious self" or "soul". Animals, plants, magnets, the universe all have one. In Homer, "ghost", and "in swoons it leaves the body". In Plato, divided into "λογισμὸν καὶ θυμὸν καὶ ἐπιθυμίαν". Also "when concrete the Homeric ψ. is rather warm blood than breath, cf. Il.14.518, 16.505, where the ψ. escapes through a wound; cf. ψυχοπότης, ψυχορροφέω"

\u03b5\u1f50\u03b1\u03b3\u03b3\u03b5\u03: "announce" in order that we might form "announcer", "announcement" etc in other forms. But not just "bear a report/announcement" as ἀγγέλλω, but the -ίζω ending implies a completion of the activity; that is, "deliver the good report/announcement", or "make the thing announced".
\u03b1\u1f30\u03c4\u03ad\u03c9:
Trench: "The distinction between aiteo and erotao is as follows. Aiteo is the more submissive and suppliant term. It is consistently used to refer to an inferior's seeking something from a superior (Acts 12:20), of a beggar's seeking alms from a potential donor (Acts 3:2), of a child's seeking something from a parent (Lam. 4:4; Matt. 7:9; Luke 6:11), of a subject's seeking something from a ruler (Ezra 8:22), and of a man's seeking something from God. In classical Greek, erotao never means "to ask" but only "to interrogate," or "to inquire." Like rogare (inquire), erotao implies an equality between the one who asks and the one who is asked as a king with another king (Luke 14:32)or if not equality, then a familiarity that lends authority to the request."

Moulton in Proleg. p 160 quotes Mayor who makes the case that the middle voice "implies using the words, without the spirit, of prayer" and continues "For the alternation of active and middle in the Herodias story, Blass's ingenious remark may be recalled, that "the daughter of Herodias, after the king's declaration, stands in a kind of business relation to him".
\u1f10\u03ba\u03b4\u03b9\u03b7\u03b3\u03: Not just "describe" (LSJ) but "lead out through". The Latin word "educate" itself means "lead out" (http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=educate) and I think carries the relationship better.
\u03c6\u03c9\u03bd\u03ad\u03c9:
Although "call out" is probably the closest English gloss, we want to avoid a collision with καλέω which, although it means "summon" more than "make a sound" is probably best rendered as "call" (esp since used as e.g. "call his name John").

Any reattempt at rendering this should pay close attention to Mk 1:26 "καὶ φωνῆσαν φωνῇ μεγάλῃ" = "and when it voiced (to) a great voice".
\u03ba\u03b1\u03b8\u03b5\u03cd\u03b4\u03: Not just sleep (ευδον) but kata = "falling" + sleep.
\u1f00\u03c0\u03cc\u03bb\u03bb\u03c5\u03:
Active = "lose" and passive = "be lost (by someone)" but middle more at "got oneself lost".

There's a strong tradition to translate this as "destroy" (which in English carries a strong sense of violence) but I think as strong as we can get is "get rid of", or we lose the sense of loss. Even Moulton and Milligan have a reference to "loss of pigs" rather than "death" or "destruction". For example, Luke 15:9 "εὗρον τὴν δραχμὴν ἣν ἀπώλεσα" ("I found the drachma which I lost") is hardly "which I destroyed".

Probably related to ὄλεθρος.
